s.text: McNeill does not mention this, but it is true.
Long, luxurious smooches can end in a sound like planes of glass rubbing, or even in a cheep.
I would recommend these metaphysical exercises as a cheap alternative to reading The Face and The Hand .
For our simian ancestors in the trees, falling from branch to branch was a normal mode of locomotion, but you had better have a prehensile paw for grabbing the crucial limb at the last moment.
(Remember, Homo sapiens lived side by side with Neanderthals for many thousands of years, and we differed from them chiefly in the face.)
Chinese, English, and Indian women prefer the same Greek men; Hispanic and black Americans agree on which newly arrived Asian women are the genuine babes, and so on.

The true relevance of lateralization of function will be ascertained only by careful research that acknowledges that aspects of this function develop throughout the life span, beginning at birth, if not before.
If the face has been getting longer at the bottom over the generations, it has been getting shorter (and broader) on top.
Staring at our face in the mirror, as The Face author points out, "we become first and third person at once, viewer and viewed.
Our faces are fur-less and exposed to the world so that they can be read.
But some faces are even more pleasing than the average face.
It is a trite thought, I know, but our hands and our faces come very close to being our selves--our "higher" selves, at least (our lower ones reposing in some oafish organs in the gut and below).
There are some scattered interesting bits in both The Face and The Hand , however.
What renders a face truly soul-bewitching?
The Face made me cringe a lot.

There is much maundering in The Face about the face of the Mona Lisa , the face of Jesus, the face of God.
